Can you please paste the output here? Thanks

> Can you please paste the output here? Thanks
Sure, such as the output on str2-7215-acs-1:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65380078/122713921-0e7f8700-d299-11eb-9ebb-0b68b63de1d6.png)
Additionally, if we run the test on the latest image which is built after ### [ the commit in sonic-utilities](https://github.com/kevinskwang/sonic-utilities/commit/e23c5ee3d39963ee73a5a4b33e17611106e71e20) , there will be a "HW Rev" field in the output of show psustatus CLI, that will cause pattern mismatch with the previous code.
It would be better if these changes are once tested on a real device, and we have a summary json to review.

> It would be better if these changes are once tested on a real device, and we have a summary json to review.

Added an example summary from a real device in the PR description.

> Lgtm, thanks Shi! Please note that some of the timing values from the physical device report are negative values. I am assuming this is the case because DUT has some old files or clock issue. Please check this part again.

OK, I believe that the negative values are not related to this PR. Will note the problem and check it later.
@wangxin could you please to review?
@yxieca can you please review or assign someone?

Currently, the test still fails on the latest `202012` image because the static route added is not re-distributed by `bgpcfgd`, let's wait [7492](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/7492) get included in `202012` branch.
For the new `20201231.04` image, all cases except ECMP passed. ECMP related testcases failed due to: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/7968
looks good.. just minor comments.

Updated to respond to feedback in the testing subgroup meeting. 


1. I added a scope section that clarifies that we are testing the orchestration of the firmware utilities and not their own stability.
2. I revised the test strategy for the “next” image test such that we now no longer reboot into the next image but instead decompress the squashfs and modify the files directly and then re-compress it prior to testing. This should sufficiently emulate a real life scenario.
@yxieca can you please take a look? i was not able to assign you as a reviewer.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 29d8056202525bdf51c88ef9ef8237e40a569378 into 0845fb17800f0f6adb2d8223a6daffd5eeea48f7 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-f988f93ab8850f72d86db73353e41d64ad76191d)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Asserting a tuple
There is still one LGTM alert for asserting a tuple. Please fix.

> There is still one LGTM alert for asserting a tuple. Please fix.



<!--StartFragment-->
assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
--
221 | "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth%s",
222 | self.ptf_port_index)

<!--EndFragment-->

In the above assert() both ret and rs_packet are NOT tuple (verified using isinstance()). To me this looks to be a false positive.

> > There is still one LGTM alert for asserting a tuple. Please fix.
> 
> ## assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
> 221 | "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth%s",
> 222 | self.ptf_port_index)
> 
> In the above assert() both ret and rs_packet are NOT tuple (verified using isinstance()). To me this looks to be a false positive.

The problem is that `assert()` should only take two arguments. It can be fixed with better string formatting syntax, like the following:

```python
assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
    "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth{}".format(self.ptf_port_index))
```

> > > There is still one LGTM alert for asserting a tuple. Please fix.
> > 
> > 
> > ## assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
> > 221 | "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth%s",
> > 222 | self.ptf_port_index)
> > In the above assert() both ret and rs_packet are NOT tuple (verified using isinstance()). To me this looks to be a false positive.
> 
> The problem is that `assert()` should only take two arguments. It can be fixed with better string formatting syntax, like the following:
> 
> ```python
> assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
>     "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth{}".format(self.ptf_port_index))
> ```

oops! you are right. I missed the syntax...weird that python didn't raise syntax error.

> > > > There is still one LGTM alert for asserting a tuple. Please fix.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > ## assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
> > > 221 | "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth%s",
> > > 222 | self.ptf_port_index)
> > > In the above assert() both ret and rs_packet are NOT tuple (verified using isinstance()). To me this looks to be a false positive.
> > 
> > 
> > The problem is that `assert()` should only take two arguments. It can be fixed with better string formatting syntax, like the following:
> > ```python
> > assert(len(self.rs_packet) == ret,
> >     "Failed to send ICMPv6 router solicitation on PTF port:eth{}".format(self.ptf_port_index))
> > ```
> 
> oops! you are right. I missed the syntax...weird that python didn't raise syntax error.

Yeah, it's strange. I think it was technically acceptable syntax, but it wasn't doing what you thought it was doing. It was most likely concatenating the last two elements rather than formatting the string.

I think `dualtor-mux` may not be the best name for this topology. Since this topology is specifically designed for testing the Y-cables, I think the topology name should reflect that. Also, do we intend to use this testbed to test standard (non-Y) cables?

> I think `dualtor-mux` may not be the best name for this topology. Since this topology is specifically designed for testing the Y-cables, I think the topology name should reflect that. Also, do we intend to use this testbed to test standard (non-Y) cables?

I thought since we are using dualtor config in the setup, maybe dualtor should be in the name, Should we call it `dualtor-cable` perhaps ? or just `cable`. We would have some ports which are not being used on both fanout/DUT and hence they can be used for testing other type of cables.

> > I think `dualtor-mux` may not be the best name for this topology. Since this topology is specifically designed for testing the Y-cables, I think the topology name should reflect that. Also, do we intend to use this testbed to test standard (non-Y) cables?
> 
> I thought since we are using dualtor config in the setup, maybe dualtor should be in the name, Should we call it `dualtor-cable` perhaps ? or just `cable`. We would have some ports which are not being used on both fanout/DUT and hence they can be used for testing other type of cables.

Technically, the DuTs in this testbed will not be ToRs configuration-wise. The DuTs will simply serve as appliances for testing the cables. Therefore, if we plan to use this topology for all cable tests, both Y-cables and standard cables, maybe we should simply call it `cable-test`. If we decide to have a cable testbed with only one DuT, we could name them something like `cable-test-single` and `cable-test-dual`.

I am OK with this PR except one issue. 

In the `fabric_info.py` file, I think using string template interpolating asic_id to generate IP prefix for each ASIC is not the correct way. Probably adding ASIC ID to a base IP to get IP prefix for each ASIC is a better way.

> I am OK with this PR except one issue.
> 
> In the `fabric_info.py` file, I think using string template interpolating asic_id to generate IP prefix for each ASIC is not the correct way. Probably adding ASIC ID to a base IP to get IP prefix for each ASIC is a better way.

Addressed this by using ipaddress module in python to do the ipaddr-str to int conversion
Tagging @abdosi @sanmalho-git to keep them in loop about this change
